ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Knowledge of the connections between political issues in Italy and film evolution

This course provided me with extensive knowledge about Italian films, from the historical contexts to the directors' careers for each one. The essays were not difficult to write at all because outside knowledge wasn't required (everything we needed to know was provided in lectures).
Learned about the history of Italian film and its close ties with the history of the nation. Learned how to conduct a close analysis of a scene.
Exposure to classic Italian films, understanding of contextual Italian history and culture, how to write effective essays
Learned skills for analyzing films
This course helped me develop an understanding of how Italian film transformed from post wwII to the modern.
Film analysis methodology, Italian history/culture, writing techniques

I learned about how to critically analyze cinema. The biggest part of the course for me was learning how to write critical arguments well and carefully  my TF's comments were very, very helpful in this respect, in learning how to structure my arguments clearly and convincingly.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Marcus is incredibly engaging, passionate about Italian film and culture, and in-tune with her students. Her excitement about each film was contagious and the course material was never boring. I think the films that we covered were all phenomenal and I had only seen one of them before. The structure of the course is very well thought out and consistent (no surprises or random increases in difficulty!). The expectations of the students are very reasonable and well-communicated. You don't need ANY prior experience with film, Italian film, or Italian language to take this course. I think this is a rewarding course to take for anyone that is interested in good films or Italian culture! The only weakness I can think of is that sometimes we would have to cram two classes into one day because of the "Spring Break Days" that were sprinkled throughout the Spring 2021 semester (although this was somewhat unavoidable if we wanted to cover all of the films).

Most of the films are amazing and worth watching. To analyze them in an academic setting improves the experience greatly. But writing four papers and a final exam seems like a little too much assessment. Integrating technology better into the course could improve the learning experience.

Strengths: great selection of films
Weaknesses: could show us more examples of film critique
The course features amazing films and really interesting analysis
Strengths: Contents of the course tie together very well.
The only weakness of this course was the unreliability  of the internet. everything else was amazing: Professor Marcus, my TF, the movies. Everything.
I love this course. I wish I could have taken it in person. No weaknesses.
The lectures were great fun, and the movies were as well! I wish we could have watched them together, but I did really enjoy watching the films in the comfort of my own room.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think Zoom certainly made it difficult for the discussion times during the course to be as open/lively as Professor Marcus wanted. She constantly encouraged the class to engage, comment, and unmute but most of the time only 2-5 people would actually talk out of the 20+ in the course. Perhaps additional discussion sections added to the course or extra time for small breakout rooms would facilitate more participation during virtual learning.
Slideshows, with clips, dates, terms, and images organized together would improve the experience (over general discussion and holding up of cards with occasional screen sharing of images and scenes).
Regular seminar time is already pretty engaging
I think the focus on live virtual lectures worked really well for this course. It facilitated discussion and allowed us to cover topics in depth all at once.
Sometimes would have been nice to have recorded lectures, but I understand that attendance might have dropped. In general, worked really well.

The lectures worked well over Zoom, and the movies were fine to watch on my laptop  it worked fine! Prof. Marcus was occasionally very frustrated with her technological difficulties, but it was never too much of a problem.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I am not a film major, nor do I speak Italian, but I greatly enjoyed this course from start to finish. Learning about Italian film was very interesting.

Absolutely! This was my favorite course so far! If you love anything about Italy or Italian culture I highly recommend taking this course because it is a lovely tour through Italian cinema facilitated by a professor who is enamored with Italian film herself. In addition to the films discussed throughout the course, each week we received a filmography for each director (a.k.a. even more amazing films to watch in your free time if you want!). As a student of Italian language this was a very useful supplemental course for me (even though it is taught entirely in English, many of the films are in Italian with English subtitles and hearing so much Italian really reinforced my learning throughout the semester). I give this course "Cinque Stelle"!!
If you are interested in film, or Italian film, definitely.
Yes- super awesome introduction to Italian film and relatively low-stress throughout the semester (just 4 essays and a final, no midterm). Grading may vary by TA
Very highly!
Absolutely. Professor Marcus is a wonderful instructor and has clearly spent tons of time with the material. The films themselves are also great!

I would absolutely  recommend this course. If you love Italian culture, or if you love movies, this course will greatly expand your understandings and beliefs of both. You will come out of the course with a better understanding of Italy's impact on the world and the immense power films have on individuals and society.

Yes! The teaching staff and Penny are great! I really learned so much from this course and found the entire structure to be really helpful for learning. Also, so many great films to share with friends and family.
Yes! It's not too heavy, you learn a lot, can put in as much time as you want, the readings are interesting, and the films are great!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This course was taught through live virtual lectures and virtual discussions. There were no additional discussion sections but students were encouraged to comment during the Tuesday and Thursday lecture classes.
Course was a lecture but with lots of student input and discussion.
N/A
Live virtual section to discuss papers
Zoom and screen shares of movie clips
There were live Zoom meetings with TFs to discuss our papers, which were Incredibly! helpful.
